sn11.6:1.2: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
sn11.6:1.3: In that battle the demons won and the gods lost.
sn11.6:1.4: Defeated, the gods fled north with the demons in pursuit.
sn11.6:1.5: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his charioteer Mātali in verse:
sn11.6:2.2: in the red silk-cotton woods with your chariot pole.
sn11.6:2.3: I’d rather give up our lives to the demons
sn11.6:2.4: than deprive these birds of their nests.’
sn11.6:3.1: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. And he turned the chariot back around, with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds.
sn11.6:3.4: The demons will have to fight the gods a second time!’ Terrified, they retreated right away to the castle of the demons.
sn11.6:3.5: And that’s how Sakka came to win victory by principle.”
